facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 179 of 1963 is an appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 23, 1962 of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 207 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: CIVIL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Civil Appeal No. 179 of 1963. Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated October 23, 1962 of the Madras High Court in Writ Appeal No. 207 of 1962.

facts.text: A single judge of the Madras High Court set aside the order of the State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras, allowing the appellant company's appeal granting them a permit to ply a bus on route No. 5 in Erode Town.

anchor.surface_text: The judgment of the Court was delivered by MUDHOLKAR J.-A single judge of the Madras High Court set aside the order of the State Transport Appellate Tribunal, Madras, allowing the appellant companypanys appeal granting them a permit to ply a bus on route No. 5 in Erode Town.

facts.text: An appeal preferred against the single judge's decision by the appellant company under cl. 15 of the Letters Patent was dismissed in limine.

anchor.surface_text: An appeal preferred against his decision by the appellant companypany under cl. 15 of the Letters Patent was dismissed in limine. Against that decision the appellant has companye up before this Court by special leave.

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore invited applications for the grant of six permits for stage carriage buses for running Erode Town service.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority, Coimbatore invited applications for the grant of six permits for stage carriage buses for running Erode Town service. On route No. 5 two stage carriage buses were sought to be introduced.

facts.text: On route No. 5 two stage carriage buses were sought to be introduced.

anchor.surface_text: The appellantas well as respondents 1 and 2 and some others, had applied for the grant of all the six permits, including two on route No. 5.

facts.text: The appellant as well as respondents 1 and 2 and some others had applied for the grant of all the six permits, including two on route No. 5.

anchor.surface_text: The appellantas well as respondents 1 and 2 and some others, had applied for the grant of all the six permits, including two on route No. 5. The Regional Transport Authority at its meeting held on March 16, 1961 companysidered the applications,

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority at its meeting held on March 16, 1961 considered the applications, granted four permits out of six to four existing operators and on route No. 5, which was a new route, it granted a permit to each of the two respondents.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority at its meeting held on March 16, 1961 companysidered the applications, granted four permits out of six to four existing operators and on route No. 5, which was a new route, it granted a permit to each of the two respondents.

facts.text: Route No. 5 was a new route.

anchor.surface_text: granted four permits out of six to four existing operators and on route No. 5, which was a new route, it granted a permit to each of the two respondents.

facts.text: Aggrieved by this order the appellant preferred an appeal before the State Transport Appellate Tribunal.

anchor.surface_text: Aggrieved by this order the appellant preferred an appeal before the State Transport Appellate Tribunal which held that the appellant should be proffered to the respondent No. 1.

facts.text: The Tribunal held that the appellant should be preferred to the respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: which held that the appellant should be proffered to the respondent No. 1. The Tribunal thus did number interfere with the order of the Regional Transport Authority in so far as the permit granted to the respondent No. 2 was companycerned

facts.text: The Tribunal did not interfere with the order of the Regional Transport Authority in so far as the permit granted to the respondent No. 2 was concerned.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal thus did number interfere with the order of the Regional Transport Authority in so far as the permit granted to the respondent No. 2 was companycerned but set aside its order granting a permit to the respondent No. 1.

facts.text: The Tribunal set aside the order granting a permit to the respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: but set aside its order granting a permit to the respondent No. 1. Against this order the respondent No. 1 preferred a writ petition before the High Court.

facts.text: Against the Tribunal's order the respondent No. 1 preferred a writ petition before the High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Against this order the respondent No. 1 preferred a writ petition before the High Court. That petition was heard by a single judge of the High Court and, as already stated,

facts.text: The single judge of the High Court set aside the order of the Tribunal in so far as the appellant was concerned.

anchor.surface_text: the learned judge set aside the order of the Tribunal in so far as the appellant was companycerned. The ground on which the learned judge set aside the order of the Tribunal was that the Tribunal did number state why

facts.text: The ground on which the single judge set aside the Tribunal's order was that the Tribunal did not state why the appellant should be preferred to the respondent No. 1.

anchor.surface_text: The ground on which the learned judge set aside the order of the Tribunal was that the Tribunal did number state why the appellant should be preferred to the respondent No. 1 in the matter of being given a permit.

facts.text: The Letters Patent Appeal preferred by the appellant was dismissed in limine by the learned judges who observed that the first respondent had the advantage of being given the permit by the Regional Transport Authority.

anchor.surface_text: The learned judges who heard the Letters Patent Appeal preferred by the appellant observed, while dismissing the appeal The first respondent had this advantage, viz that he was given the permit by the Regional Transport Authority.

facts.text: It is an admitted fact that though the appellant has experience of running buses on certain routes in the State it has no recent experience of running buses in a town.

anchor.surface_text: It is an admitted fact that though the appellant has experience of running buses on certain routes in the State it has numberrecent experience of running buses in a town. The appellant companyld, therefore, be properly regarded as a new entrant

facts.text: The appellant could be properly regarded as a new entrant in so far as town service is concerned. This fact has never been in dispute.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant companyld, therefore, be properly regarded as a new entrant in so far as town service is companycerned. This fact has never been in dispute. The Regional Transport Authority companysidered this circumstance against the appellant

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority considered the circumstance of appellant being new entrant against the appellant while granting permits to the respondents 1 and 2.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority companysidered this circumstance against the appellant while granting permits to the respondents 1 and 2. The Tribunal, however, adverting to Government Order No. 2265 dated August 9, 1958

facts.text: The Tribunal adverting to Government Order No. 2265 dated August 9, 1958 and observations in Raman & Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras came to the conclusion that new entrants ought to be preferred even on town routes.

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal, however, adverting to Government Order No. 2265 dated August 9, 1958 and certain , observations of this Court in Raman Raman Ltd. v. The State of Madras  1 , came to the companyclusion that new entrants ought to be preferred

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority felt that bearing in mind considerable traffic in towns and narrow roads, it is desirable to prefer existing operators to a new one.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority on the other hand felt that bearing in mind the fact that there is companysiderable traffic in towns and the roads are narrow, it is desirable to prefer existing operators to a new one.

facts.text: The Regional Transport Authority had in mind a circular dated October 14, 1960 issued by the Transport Commissioner.

anchor.surface_text: The Regional Transport Authority also appears to have had in mind a circular dated October 14, 1960 issued by the Transport Commissioner in companying to this companyclusion.

facts.text: In the circular the Transport Commissioner observed that the Government are of opinion that the town service routes should be excluded from the scope of short routes and treated as a separate category.

anchor.surface_text: In that circular the Transport Commis- sioner appears to have placed his interpretation on the Government Order already referred to in which routes have been placed in three categories short routes. medium routes and long routes.

facts.text: The Tribunal has set out the qualifications possessed by the appellant but has not considered whether the respondent No. 1 does or does not possess similar qualifications.

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. Sen who appears for the appellant contended that the learned single judge ought to have remanded the matter to the Tribunal after setting aside its order and that it could not confirm the order of the Regional Transport Authority at any rate without going into the merits of the rival claims. It is true that the order of the learned judge is not very clearly worded. But it seems to us that what he really meant was that the appeal should be reheard by the Tribunal and decided in the light of his observations. This we think should be sufficient to remove such grievance as the appellants may have.

edges.explanation: Holding h5 addresses issue i6 by interpreting the single judge's intent as requiring rehearing by the Tribunal in light of observations, alleviating the need for formal remand.
Inferred from holding.resolves_issue field

anchor.surface_text: Mr. B. Sen who appears for the appellant contended that the learned single judge ought to have remanded the matter to the Tribunal after setting aside its order and that it could not confirm the order of the Regional Transport Authority at any rate without going into the merits of the rival claims. It is true that the order of the learned judge is not very clearly worded. But it seems to us that what he really meant was that the appeal should be reheard by the Tribunal and decided in the light of his observations. This we think should be sufficient to remove such grievance as the appellants may have.
